title: Introduction
content: Hello everyone, my name is Vishvamsinh Vaghela, a 3rd-year computer science student at LJ University. I had the incredible opportunity to be selected for Google Summer of Code 2024 with the Postman organization, where I contributed to the AsyncAPI initiative as an open-source developer. My journey has been fueled by a passion for web development and collaborative open-source contributions
Contact: You can click on my name in the footer, which will take you to my GitHub profile. It contains all my contact details like email-address and social handles, including LinkedIn and Twitter.

title: 1. What is Open Source?
content: Software with freely available source code for viewing, modification, and distribution
Built on principles of transparency, collaboration, and community ownership
Powers 80% of the internet (Linux, Apache, etc.)
Drives innovation in AI (TensorFlow, PyTorch)
Enables modern web development (React, Vue.js)
Learn from real-world codebases and build meaningful portfolio

title: 2. What is GSoC?
content: Founded in 2005 by Google to promote open source
19,000+ students from 112 countries have completed GSoC
Over 800 open source organizations supported
Paid remote internship (12-22 weeks) with one-on-one mentorship
Real-world project development with flexible working hours
Many contributors become maintainers or work at major tech companies

title: 3. GSoC Statistics 2024
content: Over 2,800 mentors and organization administrators
43,984 applicants from 172 countries
9,107 proposals submitted by 6,518 applicants
1,220 GSoC contributors accepted from 73 countries

title: 4. Journey with AsyncAPI
content: Opened my first PR at AsyncAPI 1.5 year ago
Started with Good First Issues (GFI), such as fixing CSS and minor bugs, to get familiar with the codebase
Worked on creating the financial summary page
Added an adopters section to the case studies
Wrote tests using Cypress, although the pull request wasn’t merged because cypress was removed from the project
Contributed to the migration of the AsyncAPI website from JavaScript to TypeScript and successfully completed it as part of a team
Applied for and got selected for Google Summer of Code 2024 at Postman (my project was transferred to AsyncAPI)
Worked on writing tests for Node.js scripts using Jest as part of GSoC for the AsyncAPI website.
Started with little knowledge of Open Source but grew through consistent effort and made it to GSoC
Initially doubted my abilities but achieved milestones through dedication and belief in myself
As of today, while I am writing this, I have had 30+ PRs merged in AsyncAPI

title: 5. Why Consider GSoC?
content: Gain hands-on experience working on real open-source projects.
Receive guidance from experienced mentors and developers in the open-source community
Improve technical skills, including coding, testing, and software development practices
Connect with other developers, open-source contributors, and organizations worldwide
Receive financial support for contributing to open-source projects during the summer
Enhance your resume with a notable open-source contribution and experience working in a collaborative environment
Increase visibility among potential employers and open doors to future career opportunities in the tech industry
Develop problem-solving, communication, and teamwork skills while contributing to meaningful projects

title: 6. Are You Good Enough?
content: Basic programming knowledge required
Git fundamentals needed
Communication skills are essential
Consistency valued over expertise
Learning attitude over current knowledge
Many first-time contributors and non-CS students succeed

title: 7. Getting Started
content: Master Git basics (clone, commit, push, pull)
Learn one programming language well
Familiarize with basic command line usage
Use resources like Odin project and freeCodeCamp
Set up development environment (VS Code, Git)
Study organization-specific tutorials

title: 8. Choosing an Organization
content: Evaluate technology stack familiarity
Assess project complexity level
Check community responsiveness
Review documentation quality
Watch for red flags: inactive repos, poor responses
Research past projects and GitHub activity

title: 9. Eligibility Details
content: Must be 18+ years of age
Be a current student or working professional
Be eligible to work in the country you reside in

title: 10. Connecting with Organizations
content: Use Discord/Slack as primary communication channels
Engage in mailing lists and GitHub discussions
Read documentation before asking questions
Introduce yourself properly to the community
Share your interests and skills clearly
Help other newcomers and participate in community calls

title: 11. Starting Contributions
content: Familiarize yourself with the project's structure, dependencies, and coding standards
Begin by tackling Good First Issues (GFIs) or fixing minor bugs to get a feel for the workflow
Follow the project's setup instructions to ensure your development environment is ready
Understand the project’s goals, past issues, and contribution guidelines to align with community practices
If you're unsure about something, ask for help on forums, chat groups, or during community meetings
Make your first pull request (PR) with a small but meaningful change and follow the project's PR process
Participate in discussions, review others' PRs, and attend community meetings to build relationships
Contribute regularly, even if it's small fixes or improvements, to demonstrate your commitment and progress
After submitting your PRs, seek feedback from mentors or experienced contributors to improve your work

title: 12. GSoC Proposal Writing
content: Carefully read the GSoC proposal guidelines and requirements for the specific organization you're applying to
Provide a detailed explanation of the project, including its goals, objectives, and how it will benefit the community
Break down the project into achievable milestones with a clear timeline for each phase
Outline the technical approach you'll take to implement the project, including tools, languages, and frameworks
Highlight relevant skills, experience, and past contributions that demonstrate your ability to complete the project
Describe how you will engage with the community, ask for feedback, and communicate progress regularly
Mention how you plan to work with mentors and how you'll seek guidance throughout the project
Set achievable goals for the GSoC period, ensuring the project is manageable within the timeframe
Demonstrate genuine enthusiasm for the project and the organization to show your commitment and motivation
Review your proposal for clarity, accuracy, and completeness. Get feedback from mentors or community members before submitting

title: 13. Success Tips
content: Keep track of your tasks, deadlines, and progress to stay on top of your work
Provide frequent updates to your mentors and the community to ensure you’re on the right track
Don’t wait for issues to arise—anticipate challenges and ask for help when needed
Break your project into manageable tasks and set clear, achievable goals for each phase
Actively request feedback on your work and be open to constructive criticism to improve
Be prepared to learn new tools, frameworks, or concepts as you work on your project
Dedicate regular time to your project and avoid last-minute rushes
If obstacles come up, adapt your approach, but always keep the project’s main goals in mind
Build relationships with mentors and other contributors, as this can help with both learning and future opportunities
Strive to produce high-quality work, including well-written code and thorough documentation
Ensure you have a good work-life balance to avoid burnout and maintain productivity

title: 14. Relation with Maintainer
content: Build connection with the maintainer by engaging meaningfully in discussions and community activities.
Show respect for their time by asking well-researched, thoughtful questions.
Provide clear and concise communication about your progress, challenges, and plans.
Seek constructive feedback on your contributions and be open to implementing suggestions.
Express gratitude for their guidance and support, as maintainers are often volunteers investing their time.
Collaborate effectively by ensuring your work aligns with the project’s goals and community standards.
Establish a professional and positive relationship that could lead to mentorship and future opportunities.

title: 15. Dos and Don'ts
content: DO: Document your work comprehensively to make it clear and understandable for others
DO: Test your code thoroughly before submitting to ensure quality and functionality
DO: Maintain regular communication with your mentors and the community to keep everyone updated on your progress
DO: Stay organized with task tracking and timelines to meet deadlines
DON'T: Submit untested code that could introduce bugs or issues
DON'T: Spam pull requests (PRs); only submit meaningful, well-thought-out contributions
DON'T: Copy other proposals; your proposal should reflect your original thoughts and plans
DON'T: Disregard the community guidelines or coding standards for the project

title: 16. Timeline Breakdown
content: Timeline depends on the project size
January: Organization applications
February-March: Student exploration
March: Proposal preparation
May: Community bonding
June-August: Coding periods
September: Final evaluation

title: 17. Project Details
content: Project Size Options: Small (~175 hours) to Large (~350 hours)
Stipend Varies by Country:
India: Small (~$1,500), Large (~$3,000)
United States: Small (~$3,000), Large (~$6,000)
Stipend paid based on project size and country, distributed over the program's duration
Flexible Duration: 10 to 22 weeks, part-time (15-30 hours per week)
Project scope varies based on size, from small bug fixes to large feature implementations
Workload includes coding, documentation, testing, and community engagement
Final deliverables should include well-documented, tested, and production-ready code

title: 18. Common Q&A
content: Q: How do I know if I’m eligible for GSoC? A: You must be a student, at least 18 years old, and meet the eligibility requirements outlined by Google
Q: Can I apply to multiple organizations? A: Yes, you can apply to multiple organizations, but you should tailor each proposal to fit the specific organization's needs
Q: Do I need to have prior experience with open source? A: No, prior experience is not required, but it’s recommended to start contributing early to gain familiarity with the project and community
Q: How do I submit my proposal? A: Proposals are submitted through the GSoC website during the application period. Follow the instructions provided by the organization you are applying to
Q: What if my proposal isn’t accepted? A: If your proposal isn’t accepted, consider applying in the future. Use feedback from mentors to improve and work on your skills
Q: Can I work on the project full-time? A: GSoC is a part-time commitment, but some students may be able to work more hours depending on personal circumstances

Q: How do I find a project idea? A: Browse the list of available projects on the GSoC website or check the organization’s project ideas page. You can also propose your own idea after discussing it with the community
Q: What happens after I get selected? A: Once selected, you’ll begin working on your project with regular check-ins, feedback, and support from your mentors throughout the summer
Q: Is there any financial support during GSoC? A: Yes, students receive a stipend based on the size of the project, with payments made throughout the program

Q: Can I participate in GSoC while taking summer courses or working? A: GSoC is part-time, so it’s possible to balance it with other commitments, but make sure you can dedicate enough time to the project

title: 19. Practical Demonstration
content: Learn to find good first issues
Practice making your first PR
Draft compelling proposals
Set up local development environment
Master Git commands and GitHub interface
Study successful PRs and merged features

title: 20. Mentor's Advice
content: Fancy proposals with unrealistic timelines or goals are the biggest red flags. Mentor's usually go for someone who has showcased their skills either through contributions to that organization or via a realistic plan laid out in the proposal with some technical background oriented to what the project is about

content: Thank you for reading and engaging with the content. Best of luck with your open source journey!
